intro: Syngonanthus micropus, commonly known as the small-fruited mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and has a unique morphology characterized by its small, fleshy leaves and berries. The plant lacks true roots and absorbs water and nutrients through its haustoria, which attach to the host's vascular system. Syngonanthus micropus is often found in disturbed habitats and can contribute to the ecological dynamics of its host species. Its presence can influence the health and diversity of the forest canopy it inhabits.
